Award.AwardTitle: 4D Imaging of Oceanic Transform Fault Material Properties Variations During the Earthquake Cycle
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many large and damaging earthquakes occur in highly populated areas, such as Indonesia, Japan, Chile and California. For that reason, forecasting earthquakes, and predicting their effects is a long-sought goal of earthquake seismology. Achieving those goals requires improved understanding of the faults and fault processes that lead to large earthquakes. That understanding is impaired by the extreme complexity of most fault and fault systems. Though they do not occur in populated areas, oceanic transform faults are comparatively simple natural laboratories, where some fundamental processes have been observed. Transform faults on the East Pacific Rise (EPR) offer a unique opportunity to study how spatial and temporal variation of fault zone properties control earthquake rupture because the largest earthquakes on these faults occur at regular intervals, and related variations of the properties in the fault zone have been observed. This project has three objectives that will advance out understanding of fault mechanics. One is to determine which spatial variations of material properties control the occurrence of the largest earthquakes. The second is to understand how fault zone properties change with time over the earthquake cycle, and the third is to understand how variations of the material properties are related to earthquake seismicity.

The broader impacts of this project include support for two young post doctoral researchers; the primary broader impact is that, while it is not directly focused on seismic hazard estimates, may be expected to lead to a better understanding of earthquake processes, with accordingly high potential societal benfits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A part of geophysics that is of major societal importance is the study of earthquakes, with the ultimate goal of predicting them or, at the least, reducing seismic risk.  Seismogenic faults in oceanic plates are often simpler than continental faults and can thus be seen as an advantageous tectonic environment for studying processes related to fault mechanics and seismicity. Our project focuses on one particular oceanic transform fault (OTF), the Gofar fault, that presents short and well-defined seismic cycles which allow us to monitor the fault behavior for a significant fraction of its seismic cycle. The main goal of the project is to detect and quantify space-time variations of the fault-zone properties and understand their relation to the different along-strike behaviors observed. Besides, the same dataset is also used to develop new techniques for improving measurements on Ocean Bottom Seismometers (OBS).

 

Careful location of microseismic events provide a very precise delineation of the fault. This shows that no geometric structure in the fault trace can explain the barrier-like behavior of some segments and that, on the contrary, the fault trace is very linear and continuous. Moreover, the micro- earthquakes location shows that seismicity is very localized (<600 m wide). These results confirm the common view of oceanic transform faults but give an unprecedented image of such a fault. Finally, the comparison with the bathymetry shows that the fault trace obtained follows the bathymetry very accurately and delineates two branches in agreement with the ridge structure. 

 

We found that the part of the fault that breaks regularly in large earthquakes is characterized by efficient seismic wave propagation suggesting that it is composed of intact rocks. Adjacent segments, with different seismic characteristics, are thought to be composed of damaged rocks could explain the ability to stop large ruptures. Along-strike seismicity also shows a very strong segmentation. The seismicity tends to occur at the boundaries of zones with different physical properties, suggesting that the seismicity is strongly controlled by the along-strike structural variation.  With this new understanding we can try to recognize similar such relationships in continental fault zones.
